docs.title: Code From Anywhere Course
docs.description: This course is a work in progress... Check back soon!

docs.title: CSS
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Setting a goal
docs.description: The first step is deciding what you want to get out of this course. It's very important that you're not only going to read the stuff I say here on these pages. You need to practice in order to become handy.

docs.title: HTML
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: JSON
docs.description: JSON means JavaScript Object Notation. JSON is used in lots of places. It is very easy to use because JSON can directly be imported into JavaScript and be parsed as a JavaScript Object. It's great!

docs.title: Make something!
docs.description: Now that you know the basics... Go and make something cool! You can use html in .html files, markdown in .md files, css in the style attrubute of your html tags (or use a .css file), json files have the .json extension...

docs.title: Markdown
docs.description: Markdown is a handy way to write documents. You can save any file as a [filename].md file to create a markdown file. It uses a couple of syntactic rules that let you style things.

docs.title: Setting things up
docs.description: To start developing, I recommend the VSCode editor. I recommand having a Mac but it's not needed. It'd also be good to install Node.js already, but you'll only need that in the "frontend" section.

docs.title: Knowing your terminal
docs.description: Important commands (I'll explain later, in the meantime you can google yourself. This should be second nature for you)

docs.title: Become a frontend dev
docs.description: I strongly suggest not to do the whole course. I think that now you already know enough to become a front-end developer. Seriously, that's all you need to know!

docs.title: Configurations
docs.description: Don't get lost in them! It's easy to do though, so be careful. On this page I'll let you know which configurations you need to know about for sure.

docs.title: Data Storage
docs.description: Coming soon...

docs.title: Deploy your frontend
docs.description: You probably like to show your website to some friends. That's easy! We only need to deploy it. For deployment to our own domain, we're using Vercel, GitHub and NameCheap

docs.title: Git
docs.description: Git is needed for version control, deployment, and for collaboration in a team.

docs.title: NPM packages
docs.description: You need to know the following

docs.title: Tailwind
docs.description: The future of CSS is no CSS! This looks like css but it's making it much easier to apply.

docs.title: More Typescript
docs.description: Now it's going to get interesting! Until now we've only learnt about markup languages and JSON, a very simple file-format containing only data.

docs.title: React with Typescript
docs.description: Setup

docs.title: Become a full-stack dev
docs.description: You're now a full-stack developer. You may not know everything of course... But you'll know the basics. Just get that ‚Ç¨75 an hour freelancing gig, and keep reading!

docs.title: Core
docs.description: In /packages/core you'll want to define your type interfaces and endpoints.

docs.title: Deploy backend
docs.description: This is a big one!

docs.title: Deploying with expo
docs.description: Once you shared the UI with react-with-native your app should also work fine on native cross-platform mobile with sensible's built-in expo support.

docs.title: Deployment web
docs.description: Sensible is built on top of a yarn workspace. Your Next.js frontend relies on other packages inside the sensible project, so they also have to be installed and built.

docs.title: Dev Dashboard
docs.description: On the dev dashboard you'll find all you need to know about your app

docs.title: Going full stack
docs.description: Let's go full stack baby! Yes, that's right.

docs.title: Server
docs.description: On the server (/apps/server) you'll implement your endpoints and make them available to the public.

docs.title: UI
docs.description: In the /packages/ui folder you'll create most of your UI. This UI can be shared with multiple frontends this way, not just Next.js!
